article_title: San Antonio unemployment rate inched up in January
article_text:
San Antonio unemployment rate inched up in January

The San Antonio region’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose slightly in January to 4 percent from 3.9 percent in December, according to data released Monday by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

article_metadata.description: While transportation and pipeline companies might shed workers, San Antonio’s health care sector could show increasing demand as the Affordable Care Act prompts more people to sign on with insurance companies and Medicaid, he said.  According to non-seasonally adjusted date reported Friday by Workforce Solutions Alamo, San Antonio’s mining and logging sector, which includes the oil and gas industry, showed a loss of 100 jobs when comparing January to December.  Since the beginning of the year, nearly a third of the drilling rigs in Texas have been idled.  Workforce Solutions Alamo also reported Friday that the San Antonio metropolitan area added 31,600 jobs between January 2014 and this January, for a 3.4 percent annual growth rate, said Gail Hathaway, the executive director of the job agency.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lynn Brezosky, Staff Writer
